goal:
The Long Distance Fleet Advisory Council (LDAC) is an EU fisheries stakeholder-led body recognised in the CFP Regulation (UE) No 1380/2013 as an organization aiming a European Interest.

It represents stakeholders of both the fishing sector (including catching, processing and marketing sectors, and trade unions) and other groups of interest (environmental and development for cooperation NGOs and civil society organisations).

It is currently composed by 52 members from 12 EU coastal Member States.

Its main goal is to promote the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of fishing resources.

Its mission is to provide advice to the European Commission and to the EU Member States on matters pertaining to the External Dimension of the CFP, namely:
* Sustainable Partnership Fisheries Agreements with Third Countries (SFPAs)
* Regional Fisheries Management Organizations (RFMOs) in which the EU is a contracting party,
* Horizontal and cross-cutting issues such as international ocean governance, blue growth, SDGs, social sustainability of the fisheries value chain, etc

Its main focus of work is on three core areas:

1. Maritime safety and decent conditions at work in Fishing (EU Social Dialogue Committee, ILO, IMO...)
2. Fight against Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated (IUU) fishing. The LDAC is actively engaged with the European Commission, the Member States, the European Fisheries Control Agency (EFCA), industry, R&D companies and NGOs on this topic.

3. Improving transparency and regional governance in decision making in fisheries management in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans; and advocating for enhanced participation of fisheries stakeholders in international fora (e.g. UN, FAO, IUCN, OECD, ILO, RFMOs...)
interests: Climate Action, Consumers, Employment and Social Affairs, Environment, External Relations, International co-operation and development, Maritime affairs and fisheries, Public Health, Regional Policy, Trade

EU Common Fisheries Policy

- Fight against Illegal, Unregulated and Undeclared Fishing (IUU)
- International Governance of the Oceans and the Seas
- Regional Fisheries Management Organisations
- Ecosystem based approach to fisheries management (EBAFM) and its implementation outside EU waters
Maximum Sustainable Yield
- Biodiversity Beyond National Jurisdiction.
- Implementation of trade agreements, including GSP+
Social, Labour and Human Rights of Fish Workers (including crews, processing plants and fishing communities in third countries)
- Food security
- Control of imports and traceability of fish products
- Development for Cooperation and Fight against Poverty
- Achievement of UNDP 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, in particular 2 (zero hunger), 8 (decent work and economic growth), 14(life below water) and 17 (partnership for the goals).
